data.name: IX.br (PTT.br) São Paulo
data.notes:
This is the Peering information for the IX.br (PTT.br) Route Servers.

There are two route servers per IXP for redundancy purposes in Sao Paulo

For IX.br (PTT.br) Sao Paulo we recommend a maximum-prefixes setting 400K for IPv4 and 300K for IPv6

The following communities are implemented:

Do not advertise the prefix for ASNxx:
* 16-bit ASN: 65000:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT: 65000: ASNxx or RO:65000:ASNxx

Announce the prefix for ASNxx only:
* 16-bit ASN: 65001:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT:65001:ASNxx or RO:65001:ASNxx

Add one prepend in the AS-Path of the prefixes sent to the ASNxx
* 16-bit ASN use the communitie 64601: ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN use the communitie RT:64601:ASNxx or RO:64601:ASNxx
  
Add two prepends in the AS-Path of the prefixes sent to the ASNxx
* 16-bit ASN: 64602:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT:64602:ASNxx or RO:64602:ASNxx

Add three prepends in the AS-Path of the prefixes sent to the ASNxx
* 16-bit ASN: 64603:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT:64603:ASNxx or RO:64603:ASNxx

Communitie to identify the ASN that sent the prefix to the route server:
* 16-bit ASN: 26162:SOURCE_ASN
* 32-bit ASN: RT:26162:SOURCE_ASN or 
* 32-bit ASN: RO:26162:SOURCE_ASN

Communities added by the route server  to identify the location where the prefix was received:
* 16-bit ASN: 26162:65011
* 32-bit ASN: RT:26162:65011 or RO:26162:65011

Registro.br(Whois/RDAP):
* 26162:65111 - valid on Registro.br(Whois/RDAP) database
* 26162:65112 - unknown on Registro.br(Whois/RDAP) database
* 26162:65110 - invalid on Registro.br(Whois/RDAP) database (prefix will be discarded)

RPKI:
* 26162:65131 - RPKI valid 
* 26162:65132 - RPKI unknown
* 26162:65130 - RPKI invalid (prefix will be discarded)

Stub BR(Valid on Registro.br and directly connected to IX.br):
* 26162:65180 - Stub BR
* 26162:65181 - not Stub BR

data.name: THAILAND IX (TH-IX)
data.notes:
TH-IX is an Internet Exchange Point (IXP) located in Thailand, serving as a crucial hub for internet traffic exchange within the country. TH-IX facilitates the exchange of internet traffic between various ISPs such as AWN (AIS), AIS|3BB, TRUE-DTAC and NT, CDNs and other network operators. These exchanges help improve network performance, reduce latency, and enhance internet connectivity for users in Thailand. TH-IX plays a vital role in optimizing internet infrastructure and supporting the growth of digital services in the region.services in the region.

Approximate prefix: 12,000 prefixes.

data.name: KCIX
data.notes:
### How to participate?
Please visit http://kcix.net and fill out the small form on the front page or email peering@kcix.net to connect. 

Now offering 100G/40G ports in 1102 Grand and 1530 Swift.

### Max Prefix Settings
Recommended limits to allow for future growth  
IPv4: 200000  
IPv6: 100000  

### Route Server Communities:
 0:$peerasn to exclude your routes to $peerasn
40542:$peerasn to include your routes to $peerasn
0:40542 to exclude your routes from all peers

### Official KCIX Extensions:
St. Louis, Missouri via [STLIX.net](http://stlix.net)  
[https://www.peeringdb.com/ix/2585](https://www.peeringdb.com/ix/2585)

Houston, Texas via [HOUIX.net](http://houix.net)  
[https://peeringdb.com/ix/2835](https://peeringdb.com/ix/2835)

Springfield, Missouri via [SpringIX.net](http://springix.net)  
[https://www.peeringdb.com/ix/3195](https://www.peeringdb.com/ix/3195)

Minneapolis, Minnesota via [MNVoIP.com](http://mnvoip.com)  
[https://www.peeringdb.com/net/4044](https://www.peeringdb.com/net/4044)

### Mailing List:
Please email info@kcix.net if you wish to be subscribed to the KCIX members mailing list.

data.name: InterLAN-IX
data.city: Bucharest, Arad, Cluj-Napoca, Constanta, Craiova, Iasi, Suceava, Timisoara
data.notes:
*InterLAN is a neutral Internet Exchange in Romania, with seven POPs located in main datacenters in Bucharest ([NXDATA-1](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/439), [NXDATA-2](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/978), [Voxility IRD](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/1635), [M247 Europe](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/2188), [iNES](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/772), [Teletrans HB](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/2199), [Radiocom](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/8488)) and other seven POPs over a distributed traffic exchange platform for local service providers in major cities: Arad ([CobraNET](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/5979)), Cluj-Napoca, Constanța, Craiova, Iași ([Top Telecom](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/5990)), Suceava, Timișoara ([UPT](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/5986)). One POP outside Romania is available in Frankfurt, Germany, at [Equinix FR5](https://www.peeringdb.com/fac/60).*

*Daily peak traffic is 500 Gbps and over 120 ASNs are connected. Major CDNs are present as well as five anycast DNS root servers ([D](https://www.peeringdb.com/net/3924), [E](https://www.peeringdb.com/net/3924), [F](https://www.peeringdb.com/net/9897), [K](https://www.peeringdb.com/net/1486), [L](https://www.peeringdb.com/net/618)), [AS112](https://www.peeringdb.com/net/10664) and [RRC22](https://www.peeringdb.com/net/621) from [RIPE NCC](https://www.ris.ripe.net/peerlist/rrc22.shtml). InterLAN is using [IXP Manager] (https://www.ixpmanager.org) tool for peering management. Available services are: Public Peering, Back-up Port, Private VLAN, Virtual Patch, Multicast Streams, IXP Reseller.*

*For peering with the InterLAN route servers, please see [InterLAN Route Servers](https://www.peeringdb.com/net/11965).*

data.name: IXPN Lagos
data.notes:
The Layer 2 IXP was established in 2006. The Internet Exchange Point of Nigeria (IXPN) is known for a  neutral and not-for-profit organization focusing at facilitating the exchange of internet traffic among the ISPs and other network operators in Nigeria.  The IXPN is a key player in the global Internet ecosystem and a hub for many other important networks in Africa. By allowing ISPs and other networks to exchange traffic, IXPN helps to reduce costs and improve the efficiency of the internet in Nigeria. It enhances the possibilities the internet is accessible to all Nigerians, regardless of their geographic location.

The primary goal of IXPN is to reduce the cost and complexity of Internet traffic exchange in Nigeria, by allowing ISPs to directly interconnect their networks and exchange traffic locally, instead of routing traffic through international gateways. The infrastructure assists to make Internet access more affordable for everyone, regardless of their financial situation. This can increase access to educational materials and other resources that can bridge the information gap.

IXPN provides a range of services and infrastructure to support Internet traffic exchange, including physical infrastructure such as data centers, routers, and switches, as well as virtual infrastructure such as route servers and peering databases. It also provides technical assistance and training to its members to ensure that they can effectively utilize the IXPN infrastructure and services.

Today, IXPN is the largest and most active Internet Exchange Point in West Africa, with over 120 members, including ISPs, content providers, and telecommunications companies. Our system is instrumental in enhancing the quality and accessibility of Internet services in Nigeria, while also serving as a crucial hub for Internet traffic exchange throughout the region.

400G mesh between 7 locations, and additional 100G paths. Big CDN - Please talk to us before choosing a datacenter in Calgary, so we can remain overbuilt.

- 400G: CAD $10,000 NRC, no MRC
- 40/100G: CAD $2500 NRC, no MRC
- 1/10G/25G: CAD $500 NRC or give us an optic, no MRC

Will happily issue additional invoices (with line item of your choice) to support the IXP growth.

data.name: YXEIX
data.notes:
YXEIX Route Servers offer secure route filtering using IRR data and RPKI ROA.

For prefixes to pass validation on the YXEIX route servers, peers must maintain IRR route objects, RPKI ROAs, and/or ARIN WHOIS OriginAS entries. 

Peers with downstream networks must also maintain IRR as-set objects, and place the as-set name in the peeringdb.com "IRR Record" field.

Please contact the YXEIX (Info@YXEIX.com) if you require assistance or would like more details about our filtering platform. 

Happy Peering!

data.name: STACIX
data.notes:
*Free 10GE ports until further notice. Covering Cross Connects for the first few networks connecting.*

STACIX aims to bring affordable peering to networks of all sizes, not just large ISPs, while still providing access to high-volume networks.

For pricing information please visit https://stacix.net/pricing/

A variety of connectivity related services are available via STACIX. Please visit https://stacix.net/pricing/ for additional information.

**Instructions for joining:**
First, please fill out the form at https://stacix.net/get-connected/. Once the physical access is ready, you will be placed in our quarantine LAN. There we will make sure that only allowed protocols (IPv4, IPv6, ARP) are used and protocols like Proxy ARP, OSPF and DHCP are disabled. These checks usually takes about 15 - 60 minutes and once they are completed, you will immediately be put into the production LAN.

**Remote Connections:**
It is possible to join remotely via resellers at the following datacenters:
- Hetzner NBG1

You may also connect by purchasing transport to any STACIX-enabled datacenter. Please note that connecting via any type of tunnel or VPN is strictly prohibited.

data.name: SIIX IXP POMEZIA (ITALY)
data.notes:
# SIIX - Southern Italy Internet Exchange

SIIX, located in Southern Italy, enables ISPs, content providers, cloud services, and CDN providers to efficiently interconnect and exchange IP traffic. This presents a cost-effective solution for enhancing network performance in Italy and globally.

## Key Offerings

- **Free Ports**: To encourage network growth, SIIX offers free port connections.

## Network Operations

- **ASN**: Operating under ASN 49245, providing a reliable Internet exchange environment.
- **BGP Community Support**: Advanced BGP community support for effective traffic management.

### BGP Community Tags and Their Functions:

- `49245:666` - **Blackhole Unwanted Traffic**: Utilize to null route unwanted or malicious traffic.
- `49245:2001` - **Prepend Once for Route Preference**: Adjusts route attractiveness by prepending once.
- `49245:2002` - **Prepend Twice for More Specific Path Modeling**: Further influence route selection by prepending twice.
- `49245:2003` - **Triple Prepending for Maximum Path Differentiation**: Ensure optimized traffic paths with triple prepending.

data.name: IX.br (PTT.br) Boa Vista
data.notes:
This is the Peering information for the IX.br (PTT.br) Route Servers.

There are two route servers per IXP for redundancy purposes in Boa Vista

For IX.br (PTT.br) Boa Vista we recommend a maximum-prefixes setting 2K for IPv4 and 1K for IPv6

The following communities are implemented:

Do not advertise the prefix for ASNxx:
* 16-bit ASN: 65000:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT: 65000: ASNxx or RO:65000:ASNxx

Announce the prefix for ASNxx only:
* 16-bit ASN: 65001:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT:65001:ASNxx or RO:65001:ASNxx

Add one prepend in the AS-Path of the prefixes sent to the ASNxx
* 16-bit ASN use the communitie 64601: ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN use the communitie RT:64601:ASNxx or RO:64601:ASNxx
  
Add two prepends in the AS-Path of the prefixes sent to the ASNxx
* 16-bit ASN: 64602:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT:64602:ASNxx or RO:64602:ASNxx

Add three prepends in the AS-Path of the prefixes sent to the ASNxx
* 16-bit ASN: 64603:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT:64603:ASNxx or RO:64603:ASNxx

Communities to identify the ASN that sent the prefix to the route server:
* 16-bit ASN: 26162:SOURCE_ASN
* 32-bit ASN: RT:26162:SOURCE_ASN or 
* 32-bit ASN: RO:26162:SOURCE_ASN

Communities added by the route server  to identify the location where the prefix was received:
* 16-bit ASN: 26162:65095
* 32-bit ASN: RT:26162:65095 or RO:26162:65095

Registro.br(Whois/RDAP):
* 26162:65111 - valid on Registro.br(Whois/RDAP) database
* 26162:65112 - unknown on Registro.br(Whois/RDAP) database
* 26162:65110 - invalid on Registro.br(Whois/RDAP) database (prefix will be discarded)

RPKI:
* 26162:65131 - RPKI valid 
* 26162:65132 - RPKI unknown
* 26162:65130 - RPKI invalid (prefix will be discarded)

data.name: AR-IX Cabase
data.notes:
Cabase is an internet exchange that includes facilities in several cities in Argentina.

Our main network is **switched inside a city** and **routed between cities**, to keep Layer2 problems local. Each city has its own route servers.

There is also a nationwide Layer2 VLAN that bridges all connected facilities, to be used as a private peering over our public IPs, without route servers.

We also provide VLANs between peers, when the public Layer2 VLAN can't be used and peers need a private exchange over their own IPs.

data.name: ADRIA-IX
data.notes:
**SETUP IN PROGRESS**

[See Pricing here](https://adria-ix.org/Prices)

We charge no fees for best effort tunnels, nominal fees for SLA covered tunnels to avoid abuse (and keep peers interested in maintaining their sessions) and minimal fees for direct connections.

We also offer C/DWDM waves and darkfiber between all locations as well as connections to end-user sites via the national fiber optic backbone at a cheap price; meaning you can get IX access, BGP or simply transit at any optic connected location in Croatia (which includes nearly any village and all cities).

Additionally we charge a small fee if the peer is selling transit over the IX infrastructure or does not have an open peering policy/routeserver use - We think this is fair as they make money from our infrastructure while only providing value to select users.

This is a project co-financed by the European Union and the Croatian government, expected to be fully operational in Q2/Q3 2023.



**Please do not call phone numbers listed below unless absolutely necessary**

For legal and law enforcement inquiries mail [legal@adria-ix.org](mailto:legal@adria-ix.org) which directly CCs to our lawyer.

data.name: IX.br (PTT.br) Rio Branco
data.notes:
This is the Peering information for the IX.br (PTT.br) Route Servers.

There are two route servers per IXP for redundancy purposes in Rio Branco

For IX.br (PTT.br) Rio Branco we recommend a maximum-prefixes setting 2K for IPv4 and 1K for IPv6

The following communities are implemented:

Do not advertise the prefix for ASNxx:
* 16-bit ASN: 65000:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT: 65000: ASNxx or RO:65000:ASNxx

Announce the prefix for ASNxx only:
* 16-bit ASN: 65001:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT:65001:ASNxx or RO:65001:ASNxx

Add one prepend in the AS-Path of the prefixes sent to the ASNxx
* 16-bit ASN use the communitie 64601: ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN use the communitie RT:64601:ASNxx or RO:64601:ASNxx
  
Add two prepends in the AS-Path of the prefixes sent to the ASNxx
* 16-bit ASN: 64602:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT:64602:ASNxx or RO:64602:ASNxx

Add three prepends in the AS-Path of the prefixes sent to the ASNxx
* 16-bit ASN: 64603:ASNxx
* 32-bit ASN: RT:64603:ASNxx or RO:64603:ASNxx

Communities to identify the ASN that sent the prefix to the route server:
* 16-bit ASN: 26162:SOURCE_ASN
* 32-bit ASN: RT:26162:SOURCE_ASN or 
* 32-bit ASN: RO:26162:SOURCE_ASN

Communities added by the route server  to identify the location where the prefix was received:
* 16-bit ASN: 26162:65068
* 32-bit ASN: RT:26162:65068 or RO:26162:65068

Registro.br(Whois/RDAP):
* 26162:65111 - valid on Registro.br(Whois/RDAP) database
* 26162:65112 - unknown on Registro.br(Whois/RDAP) database
* 26162:65110 - invalid on Registro.br(Whois/RDAP) database (prefix will be discarded)

RPKI:
* 26162:65131 - RPKI valid 
* 26162:65132 - RPKI unknown
* 26162:65130 - RPKI invalid (prefix will be discarded)

data.name: Computing ID Internet Exchange
data.notes:
CIDIX is a community-based Internet Exchange providing high-quality peering services to enhance internet connectivity and performance. Our exchange allows for both direct peering and remote peering, ensuring flexibility and accessibility for networks of all sizes.

Key Features:

Community Focus: CIDIX is dedicated to fostering a collaborative environment among local ISPs, content providers, and other stakeholders to enhance regional internet resilience and performance.

Direct Peering: Connect directly with other networks at CIDIX to reduce latency, improve speed, and enhance the quality of your internet traffic.

Remote Peering: Access the benefits of peering at CIDIX without the need for a physical presence at our exchange point. This option allows for cost-effective connectivity solutions for networks located outside our immediate geographic area.

Flexible Solutions: Whether you're a small local ISP or a large content provider, CIDIX offers tailored peering solutions to meet your specific needs.

Reliable Infrastructure: Our robust and secure infrastructure ensures high availability and reliability, so your network can perform optimally.

Peering Policy: Open peering policy to encourage broad participation and collaboration among diverse network operators.

Join CIDIX Today:

Leverage the power of community-driven connectivity. By joining CIDIX, you can improve your network performance, reduce operational costs, and participate in a thriving community of internet stakeholders.

For more information, please visit our website or contact us at noc@computing.id.
